bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Wickliffe Rose, June 18, 1921

div1.p: Hanson discusses funding and reports on yellow fever cases. He requests more inspectors.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Wickliffe Rose, June 18, 1921
div1.opener:
DIRECCION
DE LA
CAMPAÑA SANITARIA
CONTRA LA FIEBRE AMARILLA
EL LOS DEPARTAMENTOS DEL NORTE
----
OFICINA CENTRAL
-----
Chiclayo, Peru.,
June 18, 1921.
Mr. Wicliffe Rose, General Director,
International Health Board,
51 Broadway, New York City.
My Dear Mr Rose:
div1.p:
I have just returned from a trip to Lima and a tour of inspection
of the Department of Libertad. On returning I find upon my desk your letters of
April 22, 26, May 6, 10, and 13 togather with copies of your letter to Dr. Car-
donas of May 5, to the Minister of Fomento of May 10, and your letter to Mr.
Pickett and Mr. Corrigan of May 10. In addition I have another letter from Mr.
Bauch telling me that he is sending another Check book, which (the latter) has
also been received.

In regard to the budgets, or detailed statements which I have sent
I fear that you will begin to think that I am rather vacilating. It seems that
I am unable to get up anything in the form of a budget that will actually stick.
on account of the Government failing to live up to its share of the contract. I
make plans to have the two accounts run along entirely separate, and then find
that I have practically nothing but your funds to work with. Such has been the
case since we used up the Lp 1000.0.00 which I received from the Government in
the first week of April, and I have been running practically the entire campaign
with your funds. This was one of the reasons for my trip to Lima. I have been
convinced all the time that the Government would not pay up according to the
original budgets, and for that reason made a modification approximating more
closely what I think they should be requested to pay. Yesterday on my return I
found a telegram waiting me stating that they had deposited, or rather passed a
resolution, for the Italian Bank in Chiclayo to pay the commission Lp 1200.0.00
monthly and for the same bank in Trujillo to pay Lp 850.0.00. Copy of telegram
roads as follows:

Paseo Colon, June 15,
Dr. Hanson .... Chiclayo.

Firmose resolucion para banco Italiano en Chiclayo pague una
mensualidad por valor presupuesto ese departamento o sea mil doscientas
libras y mismo banco en Trujillo abone ochocientas cincuenta librus,
valor presupuesto libertad, trascripcion va correo.- Salubridad.

If they will live up to this for a few months we will get along very
nicely, because this will cover two thirds of the entire monthly expense of the
campaign. In case we get this I will use of your funds only for special employ-
ees whom I have definitely put on your payroll, in addition to salaries and ex-
penses for Corrigan and Pickett.
EPIDEMIC IN LIBERTAD.

Under separate cover we are sending you a copy
of the report which we send to the “Salubridad” in Lima of the cases which have
been officially seen and confirmed by the Commission, up to the end of the
month of May. It appears that our work in connection with the cold weather
will prevent a sharp epidemic in the city of Trujillo. Our percentage of breed-
ing there has been reduced to 4%, as calculated by the reports turned in by the
Inspectors and Domiciliary Visitors. This figure however does not show the
work actually done because lately Dr. Tapia who is the Provincial Director had
ordered that nothing but barrels, botijas, tinajas, tanks and wells should figure
as a container or deposit examined. It happens that in Trujillo there are many
“corralaones” i.e., a species of departments or flats, which have a common door
or entrance from the street, and in many of these we have from ten to twenty
apartments, in each of which there is a family. Since the campaign has been in-
tensified all forms of containers with the exception of buckets and tin cans
have been prohibited in these apartments, with the result that the visitor or
inspector may visit as many as twenty families without a single large “deposito”
to figure in sum on which the percentage is calculated. In Trujillo we do not
find larvae in these small containers, the are emptied daily. In order to show
the true percentage of foci of breeding we will have to adopt a different basis
for the calculations and reports.

In regard to the true number of cases in the City of Trujillo we are
unable to say anything definitely.beyond what we show in the official reports.
In am quite certain that there have been many more cases, hidden in accordance
with the habits of the people and on account of a rediculous news paper pro-
paganda which has been started by a certain Physician who is looking for news-
paper notoriety. He claims that we have not properly confirmed the diagnosis
because we have not made blood cultures and recovered the leptospira icteroides
of Noguchi, and a lot of other nonsense of that kind. This togather with the
success of the antilarvae campaign which has diminished the number of adult
stegomya to such an extent that there have been very few to propagate the dis-
ease,-and there have been relatively few cases,- has been the means of crea-
ting doubt in the public mind that it actually is yellow fever. Their concep-
tion of the fever is based on the old epidemics when no effective work was done
to combat it, and the cases presented themselves in very large numbers, with many
deaths due to improper diagnosis and treatment.

In Libertad deaths have occurred in the following places; - Pacanga,
Pueblo Nuevo, Guadelupe, San Pedro, Malabrigo, Paijan, Ascope, Casa Grande, and
Trujillo. Drs. Mendoza and Cavassa are working up the statistics on the Pro-
vince of Pacasmayo and as soon as they are received I will send you a copy.

In your letter to Dr. Cardenas you speak of “10 000 cc of vaccine
a sufficient quantity for 25 000 persons” is not this an error? Unless the
dosage has been charged, or the concentration of the vaccine, this would be
sufficient for one injection of 2cc each for five thousand persons. The old
directions speak of from one to tow injections of from 1 to 2cc each.

It has been difficult to do much vaccination on account of a vicious
propaganda against it be certain elements. In addition I have had such a multi-
tude of details to attend to that I have had very little time to personally
supervise the vaccinations. Col. Vergne has done more of this than I have, and
we will work up a report on this as soon as possible.
So far I have not received any of the blanks for reporting vaccinations.

In so far as the spread south is concerned, that is the point which is
causing me the greatest worry. Our land quarantine seems to be of very small value.
The troops do not comply with their orders. If an influential individual comes along
and offers the officer in charge of the squad five soles or a pound, it usually is,
“passa senor”. We have relied on the desert of Viru, but even that is not a sure
guarantee. I have requested a double “cordon sanitario”, one immediately south of
the town of Viru, and another guarding all the principal points of the boundry be-
tween Libertad and Ancash. All this has been faithfully promised, but promises
constitutes one of the cheapest and most abundant commodities in Peru.

To have more assurance, I have engaged Dr. Enrique Caballero, for special
investigation of the coast between Libertad and Callao. For the present he has
been assisting in organizing the work in the Chicama valley, but in a few days
will start on a tour of investigation of all principal points to the south. I
will need this information as soon as possible in order to make the final dis-
tribution of my forces. He is thoroughly reliable and has the same opinions in
this matter as I do. He will figure on your payroll, salary and expenses.

Separately I transmit statement in regard to salary and expenses of
Mr. I.W. Pickett and Mr. J.P.Corrigan.
INSPECTORS.

In regard to Inspectors, I have taken everybody available
from the organization which Dr. Carter and I had in Piura. In addition we have
trained and are training a great many in both Departments (Libertad and Lambay-
eque) but the campaign is so immense that it takes time to get a sufficient
number of reliable men trained and located. It requires quite a considerable
process of selection and elimination. The revised copy of the organization as
at present established will give you an idea of the problem. I think there is
material available for inspectors, but while we are developing this material
we need reliable competent men for training them.

While I consider the expert supervision, which we have, costly I think
it is justifiable in that it will be a means of training other men to to a cer-
#5. W.R., I.H.B., June 18, 1921.
tain extent to replace it more economically. The present however I consider
the most critical period of the campaign. The number of cases is everywhere di-
minishing, and as a result the people lose their fear and have a tendency to
grow careless thinking that it is all over. At such a time we need the best help
available until we have passed the critical period, and can enter the prophyl-
actic campaign proper, by this I mean the time when we are fairly certain that
we have had our last cases, and the quarantine restrictions can be less rigorous.
This I expect to accomplish within the next three months, providing Dr. Caballero
does not find that something has escaped us farther to the south. The whole thing
depends on the latter observation; if we are still safe on this point we will do
the job this year. The presence of Corrigan and Pickett will be needed for abo
about tow to three months more to help assure this result. If any change in the
situation should suddenly arise I will notify by cable.
THE USE OF FISH.

We are using all the fish available in all sectors of
the campaign. To date my reports are incomplete, but in this Department, Mr.
Secley has distributed fish in 466 wells, for which he has used about 3000 fish.
In addition we have used them in a large number of tanks and other containers
which seem appropriate. We have a fish here which they call “majarra” which is
a voracious larva consumer, I believe even more so than the gambusia. In Trujillo
we placed a small majarra in a glass jar and added a vial of more than a hundred
larvae; the following larva morning we were unable to see a single larvae remaining.
We are using all means we can think of to combat the larvae breeding.

In conclusion I wish to thank you for your kind expressions of confi-
dence and for your generous offers of assistance. We are sparing no efforts to
make the campaign a success. Practically no one among the ranking members of the
Commission has had either Sundays or other holidays since we actively started the
campaign. We are keeping up the efforts to the limit of endurance.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully yours, Henry Hanson, M.D.,
Director of Campaign.
